description.text:
Clausevic Filament spool with bearing

  • Was created to be simple and quick to print, and to minimize the friction of the reel.

    • Features: -Fast and simple print
    -No material support required
    -Hole to stop early filament (only 1,75 for now)
    -100mm and 130mm diameter for filament
    -16mm bearing diameter (just for now)
    -30mm width space for filament Future features:
    -This thing works good also without a bearing, then i think i'll make a center part also in differents diameter.
    -Different measure of forks
    -Different method of stop filament i use a bearing 688 (8x16x5), fit perfectly!
    If you have a different bearing measure write me in comment, i'll make it!
if your printer is precise the parts fit perfectly without use the glue

title: This is a chuck pen holder for the Makelangelo 3

description.text: The Makelangelo 3.0 has a pen holder that is an off the shelf part.  Because of a lip on the end of the holder, it makes it difficult to easily mount the pen.  So I created this chuck and holder that screws onto the servo horn.

Print out the two chuck pieces and mount the collar with the arm onto the servo arm. Mount the servo onto the plate.
Insert a sharpie pen and the screw collar. tighten till pen is clamped.
you will need a modified version of the support plate.

description.text: No dual extrusion needed-- the bulbs are a separate model from the letters. :) I've always wanted some vintage movie theater marquee letters. Finally, my glamorous cat can see her name in lights. Check one off the bucket list. fistbumps her cat

Printed on my Makerbot Replicator 2 on standard settings. Gold PLA for the letters + Natural for the bulbs. No raft or supports for the letters, but use a raft for the bulbs. Plate multiple at a time to avoid tedious insanity.
  • Print letters
  • Print the bulbs
  • Assemble then refuse all incoming forms of human communication unless done via printed marquee signs
    • BONUS: Use glow-in-the-dark fillament for the bulbs

A few reasons that the change filament approach wouldn't work as well:
1) the front edge of the letters are raised above the point where the bulb meets the body, so the bottom portion of the bulb would have to be the letter's color (not a big deal)
2) i'd worry about the adhesion between the bulb and the letter along the z-axis. I would think the bulb would be very subject falling off.

comments.text: If you have v2.0 of the Eggbot Control extension, then yes centering was funky.  If you used a 1000 px high document, then the document's centerline (y=500) corresponded with where the v2.0 EC extension assumed the pen was centered. The extension always assumed that "start with pen centered" meant that the pen was resting along the line y=500.  If your document had a height of, say, 800 px, then that line of y=500 was not the centerline of your drawing....  Basically, 2.0 and earlier assumed that your document had a height of 1000 px.

3D printed Bee House Originally designed for an internal initiative from the company I work for: http://archive.wolffolins.com/work/honey-club?ghost=1 In addition to Hives, Bees also like to ‘rest’ in Bee houses. Normally, small holes in walls, wood, stone - solitary Bees just ‘chilling out’. The shape of this Bee house was inspired by the sound wave generated by a Bee in flight, Bee coloured, a planter at the top to plant a Bee attracting plant, small various sized holes around the shape and a nail hole to fix it to a wall or tree. 3D Printed in Biodegradable PLA filament - separate coloured layers and glued together using a Bee friendly glue. Research suggests that Bees are beginning to utilise plastics found in their local environment for nest making – potentially, a viable way to produce Bee homes by anyone with a home 3D printer! Enjoy!

description.text:
This is an derivation of the "Spring-loaded Replicator 2 Drive Block" by MakerBot to make it compatible with the Replicator 1 (single and dual extruder). Only minor changes has been made, as outlined in the list below. Based on the work of Thingiverse users MakerBot, whpthomas, emmett and whosawhatsis. It is the same spring-loaded arm used to squeeze the filament between the drive gear and a bearing with a constant amount of pressure. Minimizing the chance of skips due to variance in filament thickness. Both normal and mirrored models are available to fit either side of the carriage. The models are offered as STL and STEP files. A simple spring height adjustment part is included to easily increase the spring rate if needed. This piece fits over the stub on the base part. Changes:
  • Cut upper-left corner wall from the lever to fit the Replicator 1 extruder mount carriage
  • Changed the lever and base screw hole to accept a regular countersunk M3 hex screw (easy to find find)
  • Cut a slight piece off the cover to avoid resting on the drive gear
  • Decrease the bearing bolt stub diameter to fit the readily available 623ZZ bearing (3 mm vs. 4 mm ID)

Instructions:
Follow the excellent instructions by MakerBot: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53125 Parts:
  • 1x M3 x 16mm Flat Head Cap Countersunk Hex Screw
  • 1x M3 x 8mm Flat Head Cap Countersunk Hex Screw
  • 1x Ball Bearing, 3mm ID x 10mm OD x 4mm Width, typ. 623ZZ bearing
  • 1x Compression Spring, 0.360"OD 0.276"ID 0.630"-0.900"L (9mm OD x 7mm ID x 16-22mm L), 32lbs/in spring rate
    • Suppliers:
    I used the following webshops to get the needed parts:
    http://www.a2stainless.co.uk (Socket Countersunk Screw DIN 7991 - M3 16mm, 8mm)
    http://myworld.ebay.com/bearingoptions (Bearings 6000 Series - 623ZZ)
    http://myworld.ebay.com/switchedkwb/ (2x Compression / Pressure Springs - 31 x 10 x 1mm) Notes:
    The hex screws has to protrude 3 mm behind the base to properly secure the base and lever, any longer and the screw will hit the stepper motor mounting bolts. Cut the screws down to length if needed or loosen the stepper motor bolts. After mounting the lever and base to the stepper motor, make sure to leave enough slack/space to allow the lever to move freely up and down. Add some medium thread-lock if needed. The compression spring should have enough force to squeeze the filament fairly well. If rated on a scale from 1 to 10, where 1 is super soft and 10 massively hard, the spring should be in the 6-7 range.

description.text:
Out with the old in with the new.
I designed this Fan holder to fit a Noctua NF-A6x25.
It's slightly bigger than the original but that's no problem at all
and guess what ..... it works. The bigger noctua fan blows A LOT more air over the object.
And with the integrated vibration pads the noise reduction is tremendous.

Printing difficulty **... What you need:
  • A Noctua 60mm60mm25mm (NF-A6x25 FLX) (for around 18Euro on ebay)
    -(8x) washers to fill up the other end of the hotend.
  • Noctua Fan Holder.

First check if your wire colors match the instructions. (Step 13) 1)Take the Noctua Fan Holder an put the 4x Rubber Anti-Vibration Mounts all the way in the Fan Holder.
Rubber Anti-Vibration Mounts are in the Noctua Fan Box (part nr.6) 2)Put the Rubber Anti-Vibration Mounts through the hole of the Fan.
Don't forget to put the Fan right side up. (see photo) 3)Get rit of the old fan. 4)Unscrew the long studding screws. (4x) 5)Undo the coloured horseshoe under the tightner that locks the bowden tube. 6)Place the Noctua Fan Holder between the aluminium plate and the wooden part 8B. 7)Screw in the long studding screws holding the Noctua Fan Holder. (2x) 8)Fill the other side with the washers until the aluminium plate is level with the wooden part 8B. 9)Screw in the long studding screws. 10)Push the bowden tube in deeper. 11)Put the coloured horseshoe under the tightner to lock the bowden tube. 12)Take the connector of the extension cable of the Ultimaker and pull it off its own pins. 13)Put the Purple wire in the Red wire of the Noctua Fan connector.
And the Blue wire in the Black wire of the Noctua Fan connector. 14)Maybe you need to restart the Ultimaker otherwise is mide say Sleep on the Ulticonroller. And you're done.

title: Filament Spool Holder for Kossel Pro

description.text: Just a simple spool holder for the Kossel Pro that connects to the vertical OpenBeam piece and positions the spool at the right angle to feed into the filament drive.  It clips onto the beam, but also includes a hole for a screw in case the clip alone won't hold the spool holder in place.
Print with 100% infill, no rafts, no supports.

comments.text: Okay, well, we don't have the software working on ours yet, so we have yet to see the probing process.  In manually moving the head around, it appears that there could be a tiny bit of interference between the spool and the edge of the head if the probing was on the very edge of the build plate.  Is that what you are seeing?  I'm confused with the "interferes significantly" comment, as I can't see how that would be the case on our printer.
comments.author: kwmachine

comments.text: ok, discovered a bit of a problem with this thing being on the left side of the printer.  It interferes significantly with the part of the bed probe sequence that drops the bed probe down.  When mounting this, make sure that it's attached to the X vertex at about the same place as the linear rail when the extruder is centered about 90cm above the bed (top of it about 38cm above the bed).  This will give it enough clearance to run the part of the bed probe routine that drops the probe.

title: submarine body for arduino rc submarine

description.text: apparatus for an arduino remote control submarine

comments.text: This is still a work in progress, but it is just a basic apparatus. Obviously, something will have to be done within the hull otherwise it will just float when actually put in water. What that is, is up to you if you decide to make it. The two most feasible options would be to fill it with a non-buoyant substance, or simply waterproofing the Arduino alone while making the body a non-watertight apparatus. With PLA being slightly buoyant itself, this seems like the best option because it would allow the device free movement when submerged along with the safety of being able to slowly float back to the surface in the event of any malfunction or battery loss. Once I complete this, I will post all designs as well as the code.

description.text: WARNING! You must to pause the printing and drop the PCB

UPDATE: Klop2031 sent me a new version of the case with some of the geometry cleaned up.  If you're having trouble with the original, try the "fixed" version.  
I couldn't find a bumper for the Nexus 6 on Thingiverse, so I whipped one up!  Printed (very slowly) with Ninjaflex, this fits snugly around the Nexus 6 and allows access to buttons, headphone and power jacks.  Lots of rubber at the corners to absorb a fall.  It's not perfect so please let me know what needs improving.  I'd love to do this in SCAD at some point, but I'm still fastest with Blender so that's usually what I use.

IMPORTANT: You need to print this with flexible filament like Ninjaflex. ABS/PLA etc are going to be too rigid and could scrape/damage your phone. I printed this using standard Ninjaflex on a Replicator clone. I haven't done any extruder upgrades, so I have to print very slowly around 15/20mm/s at .2mm layer height. Temperatures for me were 240/45. Probably hotter than I need, but flexible filament binds up really easily so I wanted a little headroom. I didn't use any supports, the long bridge over the volume buttons somehow worked fine. I'm as surprised as you are.

comments.text: Thank you for posting this and while its far better than anything I can design it has a flaw.  While it does fit and doesn't come off the thing that makes the Nexus 6 a challenge is the curved back.  This model doesn't account for the curved back so the fit just isn't right, particularly the access holes for the USB/Headphone jacks Volume/Power buttons.  The bumper will usually block these and you have to move the case a bit every time you want to use these ports.  Its not a huge deal because it was designed for flexible material but it is a big enough deal for me to go back to my old case despite really wanting to have a 3d printed one.

author: AndrianovRoman

description.text: NEW: see the PLA Cooling Challenge http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:627590 PLA layers need to cool before the next layer is printed. If the layer is small (that is, doesn't take too long to print), it may still be warm and soft when the next one is printed which may cause visible deformation and reduces print quality. The problem can be mitigated to some extend by slowing the printing speed or using a material cooling fan but is still significant with very small layers. This thing is a dummy object that you can add in your slicer to add delays between consecutive layers of your real object. Just ''place one or more far from the actual object and print as usual. The cooler was designed to consume minimal amount of material and can be customized using the Customizer button on the right.

description.text:
To build your own little copter you need to get.
1) Carbon fibre tubes 8mm Dia x 300mm long, you will need 4 of them. I use carbon tubes from universal landing skids for a quadcopter see photo attached.
2) Some hardware for joint you need m3x25 + locknut and you will need m3x65+mm for spacers
3)Prototype PCB's
4) Print plastic parts. My setup is:
Apm 2.7
micro gps http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__64142__HKPilot_Micro_GPS_and_Compass_Module_U_BLOX_7_8g_.html
DYS 1804 2300kv motors http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=66399
AfroESC 30A (you need max for 10A)
5030 props
FPV kit
APM Power module
2A 3s Battery I include source files feel free to modify it to your needs. Work still in a progress, after flight test i will release final version. Update:
Landing skids has been added. First flight test shows very good result.
I use huge 4A - 280 gram battery for this little copter, and it flies as crazy, I could see its a bit overloaded but it handle all the weight with no problem at 65% throttle.

Print motor mounts flat side to build plate, use some support if needed.
Gps stand print top side down, use some hot glue to fix module in place. Fit carbon rods into blocks, then drill 3mm hole to fit a crews.

This is a two color cat model for dual extrusion 3d-printing.  It was generated through a simulation of reaction diffusion on a mesh.  It's derived from the MakerBot "lounging cat" model.  
We wanted to play around with using dual extrusion on our Replicator 1 printer to create textured 3D models. We're making an app that takes any 3D model and simulates reaction-diffusion on its surface to yield a 2-color 3D printable model composed of two STL's.  What do you want us to test in the app next?
Print on a dual extruder 3d-printer using two different colors of filament.

author: FallenXBlade

title: Prusa i3 E3d Bowden Mount with servo v3

description.text:
This is the latest version of my E3D mount for the Prusa i3 X-carriage, featuring an autolevel probe. This one superceeds the v2 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:246726) and it's now compatible with E3D v6. It improved dramatically the autolevel function, as my 9G cheap chinese servo tends to swing a different angle every time, ruining the consistency of probings. This linkage gearing lets the arm take a precise position EVERY time it swings up and down. Just tell it to go from max to min angle, as only the central travel of the arm wil be used to swing the probe an exact 90 degree angle, because of the gearing design. Start and end positions of the probe are secured by tiny cylindrical d3x1mm neodymium magnets (6 needed) that fits (superglued) in the provided sockets. The probe arm sports a tiny channel for the endstop wire. Once cleaned, you will need to choose the lightest and most flexible wire you can find to connect (I used earphones cable) to limit the force
it can do against the arm movement. I found that the air coming from the fan (by the way, theres an interesting fan size adapter you can use elsewhere) didnt any good to the prints, (or at least I think so). So, in case it happens to you as well, I designed a little swinging port that is opened when the probe extends, and closed by the means of a tiny rubber band (magnet closing implemented,but in beta stage:-) when it retracts, keeping the airflow out during the print. Its up to you using it or not, its a bit difficult to make, but quite funny a mechanism, like a cuckoo clock door :-) Well, you will need too a couple of sockethead M3x35 screws, to fix the rig to the Prusa x-carriage, and a M2.5 and double nut for the pivot pin of the hinge. Maybe a couple of M3 more if you wish to secure the back with the main body, but not really needed. I provide a single stl (you can split it in parts in repetier, of course) as a hint of which I think is the better print orientataion for every part. Most generic use is the bowden version, but I tend to use it with a minimal compact direct MK7 extruder I designed, that fits with the mount (as per the photo). Its not uploaded, I would do it should someone asked for it. I suppose I have left things unexplained, so please accept excuses for that and I'll try to answer any question or update this text as needed. And, I think there are not external credits to give in this part, but please, tell me if I miss something, I'll be quick to do it. Hope it helps someone!

Looks useful, I will give it a try.
One comment though, the title is misleading. Bowden means the cold end (motor an gear) are separate from the hot end ( the extruder). It is when you run your filament through tube to connect the two separate parts. Think bicycle brake lines.
comments.author: snap4ward

comments.text:
Thank you, sna4ward. Yes it may well be misleading, as I show it with a direct extruder. But in fact, my E3D is the Bowden version, and I used it that way for a while, though I prefer the direct system by now.
If you see the main picture, it only needs the coupling for the bowden tube. In the 4th picture (hope you see the same order than me) it features a direct extruder that I designed specially to link with the bowden E3D (it clips in the mount and pushes through a very short teflon tube that fills tthe "gap") and makes in fact a direct extruding.
You have then the choice to use it in either way, but If you dont want to use my direct extruder, best chance is to use it with an external extruder and a bowden tube.
I hope to have explained myself, my english not as good as I would like:-)

author: stratop80

title: Beveled 39 tooth large wades extruder gear for the Nophead Mendel 90

description.text:
This is a slightly modified version of the 39 tooth large wades extruder gear included with the Nophead Mendel 90 kit.
I've added a bevel to the first few layers so when it's printed, you don't need to sand/file each tooth to make it mesh correctly with the pinion.
There will be a slight reduction in contact area and as a result service life I guess but it's a small price to pay vs. all that sanding.
As far as I can see it's manifold, I've printed it at .3 and .1 and in both cases it came out well.
Your mileage of course, may vary.....
Cheers
D
:)

description.text:
A small 3D printable casing that slides together on any standard Magsafe Adapter for the Mac. It's designed to help protect the cable from tight bends that could damage the internal wiring.  
Pieces unfortunately don't snap together in this version, I've alternatively creates indents for an elastic band to secure the pieces together at both ends.

Materials Required:
  • Elastic Band (x2)
    • How to use:

  • Extend flaps on magsafe adapter

  • Slide top and bottom pieces of Cable Guardian together

  • Apply elastic bands into the grooves on the top and bottom
    • Design Process: I started by modeling the magsafe adapter to the best of my ability. From that I brainstormed possible designs that would require minimal assembly but still secure snugly to the adapter. While toying around with different designs I used the design process to refine what I found to be useful.

Parts required to upgrade your (RRP) Huxley to dual heads.
Designed to not limit printing size and use standard head parts.
Writeup here: Reprap Forum Two "Extruder Mount Bar"s move original extruder motor away from frame by about 5mm, and allow mounting of 2nd motor on other side - it's longer to account for non-symmetrical geometry of extruder drive. Print one of everything and make the Nozzle Bock in Aluminium from the PDF drawing. - Don't blindly drill the sizes! Adjust for tapping! I had to use helicoils....

Build Huxley hot end as per wiki/instructions/knowledge, just do some bits twice...  
Screwing the heads to the Nozzle Block is tricky 'cos they clash. I thionk I screwed the 2nd nozzle through the heater block and mount whilst holding both apart, then lock nutted.  
Be careful with your wiring. I'd advise PTFE heatshrink/Kapton around all wires anywhere near the heater block...  
When attaching to the X-Carriage the two Allen screws adjust the heights of the nozzles. use some sort of parallel to ensure they are equidistant from the bed.

description.text: Kind of had the bad luck of losing one of the clips on the IKEA PULT Lamp (at least I think that what it is called - http://www.ikea.com/sg/en/catalog/products/90192900/) So, instead of wrangling with getting a new ceiling lamp or using bent pieces of wires to hold the glass cover (dangerously!) in place, did a quick 3d model of the missing piece based on the existing ones, and got a pretty good enough holder clip again! =) Now we can lose all the pieces with impunity! Hope this helps anyone who else who happens to be missing this part! ;) (PS: A longer writeup of this is over here - http://funbiestudios.com/2013/03/3d-printing-a-replacement-clip-for-the-ikea-pult-ceiling-lamp/)

Probably want to print this at 100% infill at High Resolution (0.1mm layer height) - for maximum structural strength of the piece. 
Quite a small piece so this won't lengthen the print time by too much

remixed_from.author: bottleworks
remixed_from.title: My version of the LYMAN FILAMENT EXTRUDER

title: YALFE - YET ANOTHER LYMAN'S FILAMENT EXTRUDER

description.text:
PLEASE CHECK YALFE 3!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:951240

! PLEASE LOOK FOR YALFE V2!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:212894 This is my derivative from Mr Lyman's filament extruder enriched with some of Bottleworks' ideas. UPDATE :
-REAR PHOTOS ADDED FOR ASSEMBLY GUIDANCE PURPOSES
-FRONT PHOTO REPLACED WITH CURRENT VERSION
-TEST PRINT OF EXTRUDED ABS ADDED.
PROJECT RESULTS:

EVERYTHING IS WORKING PERFECT, I FINALLY MANAGED TO EXTRUDE FILAMENT. TEST PRINTS (CHECK PHOTOS) SHOWED THAT HOME EXTRUDED ABS FILAMENT CAN BE USED FOR 3D PRINTING.  
In 'instructions' section, i also explain some serious issues i confronted and how i solved them.

Better see Lyman filament extruder v2 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34653
and
bottleworks derivative http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32667 The file contains the drawing for the Aluminium part.
I extrude 3,00mm ~ 2,8mm filament. Nozzle hole is 2,5mm. What i added, was to put an old monitor cooling fan (something i did not use at all for 10 years now - a good friend gave it to me). It cools the hopper. I did not have to put any heat insulator as Lyman did. Also i put a switch for the nozzle fan. Almost all the parts are from Lyman's BOM.
My preliminary extrudes showed that i have to heat ABS first, in order to dry it(80 C for 1 hour). ABS absorbs moisture and makes blobs and pops when extruded untreated. Switches : (right to left)
-Main switch
-Emergency stop
-Motor switch
-Temp switch
-Nozzle fan switch (the little black dot upper left from temp switch)
The hopper cooler fan is always on
Rear view photos will follow issues. I have some issues with ABS treatment (as mentioned above). On route, next time i will try to dry some before extrusion.
UPDATE
although i heated the granules for 1 1/2 hours at 80 C, the filament quality sucks... the filament surface is rough due to pops of stinky fumes from inside the plastic.. i guess that my abs suck... i will give it a final heat for 3 hours (i have about 1/2 kilos it is a pity to through it away). New tests showed that my ABS is MORE than [email protected] However, nice sculptures can be created .... see thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:93709
This turn of things is a good lesson for us not to underestimate raw materials.
UPDATE
The problem was not the moisture, but the cooling air from the monitor ventilator. It seems that the blown air was interfering strongly with the heater section making core temp unstable. I moved the cooler underneath the hopper. Problem solved. Hopper is cool. While extruding, temp drops, causing the plastic to get hard again, and stop extruding... this is a major problem.. i think it is my fault because i did not wait enough (1/2 hours) as Lyman pointed out, for the PID to set itself... i will try to be more patient next time ....
problem solved, i also moved the temp sensor near the nozzle Another major issue is the STINK of molten plastic. i have an idea of a fume suction system, i have already the active carbon and the material to enclose it. i need to find a motor, a flexible tube, and a decent design... i am open to to suggestions...
i believe that the stink comes from the moisture that is trapped inside the plastic. this causes all the quality problems (see above)
i think with the right quality with no moisture the stink problem will be eliminated or at least will be controllable.
UPDATE
The stink comes from the BOILED plastic due to temp core instability caused by the pipe cooler. Problem solved, see above. GENERAL RULES OF THUMB FOR EXTRUDING 1 try to extrude at low temps.
2 the right plastic viscosity for extruding is that the plastic feels like 'play doh' or 'blue tack' . It must be a little bit hard. This can be controlled by adjusting core temp, extrusion velocity and nozzle cooler proximity.
3 There is not just one extrusion temp because the temp probe is not positioned at the same spot due to different extruder designs. Experimentation is required. Start at 190 C and test extrusion. if plastic comes out easily, try lower temp by 2 C.If not, raise temp by 5 C
4 If you work with plastic that is long time out of the bag, you need to dry it. Try 80C for 1~2 hours, using oven with hot AIR. the granule height layer should be low. Prefer a screen instead of a dish to help air flow through granules. I haven' tested microwave oven, but if you do, try less that a minute heating time. Materials
The main pipe is custom made from Aluminium. (thnx to Aris)
The sprocket is a standard 30 teeth 1/2 inch, machined with a lathe to reduce weight , and make a hexagon hole for the auger bit.(thnks to Savvas)
The auger bit i used is a Milwaukee (or AEG) @16mm with hexagon end shaft
The heating element is custom made, 250W, 220V.
I used a lot the L-bracket by Azdle http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2226

title: Flashforge Dreamer tall spool rod holders (left & right) and long spool rods

description.text:
This is my final version of tall spool holders and long spool rods.   These work with HatchBox, Sainsmart, and 3D Solutech 2.2lb (1kg) spools (and possibly others) on both the left and right side.  I made the holes for positioning nubs slightly larger to accomodate slight variance in position on new dreamers.  Let me know of any problems.  
I made my own version of a tall spool rod holder so that I could adapt it to fit the right side (moved forward to avoid the y-axis motor).  I also made the rods longer with a long handle that keeps spools with large center holes secure.  These are just about as tall and long as I could get without interfering with operation of the printer.  
I added cylinders to help with large size diameter spool holes and also because the spools sometimes lean towards the build plate.  The cylinders have one end bigger that goes towards the build plate to keep the spools from leaning that way.  I use the small cylinder for HatchBox spools and the large cylinder for 3D Solutech spools.

I printed the spool rods vertically.  I printed the rod holders lying on their front side with external support.  Supports were relatively easy to remove using Simplify3D but I have always had trouble with FlashPrint and supports.  I used needle nose plyers and a small pocket knife to remove the supports.  
The large end of the cylinders goes towards the build plate to prevent the spools from leaning towards the build plate.  
You will need to remove the bottom plate on the dreamer to remove the original spool holders.  Be careful not to lose the nuts on the bottom.  Then just attach the new spool holders with the same nuts and bolts from the original stand and then put the bottom back on the dreamer.

comments.text: I'm super happy with the results of printing this, though I did have one problem. For my Dreamer, which I received in early July 2015, the positioning studs don't align properly, that is, when I places the bracket over the studs I couldn't even see the screw holes. My solution was to leave the screw holes alone and cut away plastic from the bracket - from the position stud holes to the edge of the bracket. I'm guessing that Flashforge has modified the mounts such that the positioning studs are now further from the screw holes than before.
comments.author: DessertFirst2001

comments.text: This is good to know.  I based this off my printer received in Dec 2014 so it is possible the position of the studs have changed.  Do you think making the holes that go over the studs a bit bigger would help with alignment so that they fit the older and newer versions?
comments.author: DessertFirst2001

comments.text: I took some measurements of my brackets (the original brackets from Flashforge) and also took a look at the SCAD files you posted. The measurement of interest is the distance between the line connecting the screw holes and the line going through the locator post holes. If I am interpreting the SCAD correctly (I'm very new to SCAD ...in fact your posting was partly what got me interested in OpenSCAD) it looks like this distance is 10mm. Measuring that distance on my brackets it looks like 13mm. I think if you extend the Y distance of the base by 3mm then you could either put another pair of locator holes or maybe even slots that would work with both versions. I'd attempt to do that but I need a little more experience with OpenSCAD. Does my description make sense?
comments.author: tselling

comments.text: I just took a look at the code in openscad.  I have the distance from center as 12mm for those nub holes.   Measuring the original spool holders that looks about right.  I have the diameter of the holes at 5mm but looks like originals are about 8mm so I think I can just increase the diameter.

title: Sword in the stone key holder - King Arthur's Excalibur
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
King Arthur, after pulling the legendary sword Excalibur from a stone, became king.
Like the kings in other countries, he bought a huge castle.
But what a mess when it was time to go hunting : the keys were always missing !
The poor King looked after them a looooooooong time and when he finally found them and closed his castle's door, the hunt was over. With this Excalibur key holder, you'll never loose your keys : attach the sword keychain to your keys and the stone to your wall.
When you go back home, plug the sword in the stone on your wall and you'll find them next day ! If King Arthur had asked Merlin to print one, he would have found his keys every time ! Also, if you're interrested, join my discord server to discuss about 3d printing, arduino, processing, ... and find many interresting electronic project ideas : https://discord.me/electronic_projects

Stick the stone to your wall with double faced tape or a screw and plug the sword-keychain you attached to your keys in the little slot on the stone every time you go back home.
That way, your keys will be hanged on your wall.
You can also say you're the True King : in the legend, nobody except him could pull Excalibur from the stone. Note : I didn't have grey printing filament : I painted the finished object with model paint.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/dS398dRjB2W

The electronics bay on the Thing O Matic is really nifty, and looking through the clear floor into it to see the blinkenlights is great. But it's hard to get everything to fit in there, and if you hack on your bot a lot, it quickly gets irritating to have to take it all apart and open it up and do your hacking and then try to fit everything back in (probably more than before, since you're hacking new stuff on it!) and well, I got sick of it. For a while I ran with the board on my workbench next to the machine, but space is at a premium, so you have this. This is a completely non-destructive mod; you can see in the photos I was too lazy to even take out some of the bolts from the original configuration. (Ignore the giant hole in my board; it's from an earlier experiment.) So you can try it out for as long as you're hacking on your bot, then stuff everything back in when you want it to look pretty. This does make it a little harder to get light into your box if it's not lit from above. You might try something like this to solve it the way I did (in advance): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6244 These parts aren't exactly what I wanted them to be, but they work, the fit is perfect, and they don't take all day to print. Any improvements are very welcome.

Print two of the bottom part, and two of the top part.  I'm sure you don't need any instructions for this, but this space looks nicer filled up, so:
The bottom parts are intended to fit into the area near where the T-slots are; fit those first and put the board in them.  
Then put the top parts in by turning them sideways and slipping them into place.  It should be an extremely solid hold.

description.text: A sample horn for a cosplay class.
Yet another tool for levelling the building plate of Your Replicator (I)

"The Calibrator" - Levelling Aid for the Replicator When using a Replicator 3D printer, correct levelling of its base is essential for good results.
There have been some suggestions for tools on Thingiverse like
Replicator Bed Level Jig - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23257.
Since I just have a sliding caliper and no digital indicator as used in the above project I couldn't
use this of course.
For a while I did use the sliding caliper to level the plate, simply holding it upright to measure.
There's also another project on thingiverse that uses the complete calliper to do exactly that:
Vernier calliper bed leveller - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30300 I have to admit, I found this project after I had finished mine ;) But anyway, I wanted more :) I got another one of those (rather cheap) digital sliding calipers at Amazon and dissected it. http://www.amazon.de/Br%C3%BCder-Mannesmann-M-823-160-Elektronische-Digital-Schieblehre/dp/B000K2LKUM/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1363453020&sr=8-1 This is an address on Amazon Germany, but as it looks there exist lots of different brands of this specific vernier caliper that are obviously all based on the same model. What we need for the Calibrator is the display of course and the ruler which is glued and
screwed to the metal and is actually a pcb with some copper lines that are needed to detect
the position in relation to the display part. Just look at it, You'll see what I mean. Remove the glue completely as the ruler must later be able to slide freely. By now, it's obvious that my project means the destruction of the caliper, yes? Next, print out my "contraption" on a (hopefully already levelled) 3d printer.
On my Replicator I used standard settings and "raft with external support" with good results.
The slot for the ruler might have to be enlarged a little bit (scalpel, file), as I mentioned:
It's essential that the ruler can slide easily, otherwise the measurements will be less precise.
On the other hand, contact between ruler and display must not be too loose, either. Although there is a hole for screwing the display to the holder it will probably not be necessary
to do so as it all "fitteth snugly" :) The whole thing is held in place by two magnets that are inserted into the appropriate slots at
the feet. I am using round magnetic discs measuring 10 x 2 mm. If You are using different
magnets You will have to change the slots of course. If You happen to know where to get
magnets like mine: I'd like to know. Since the pcb, the ruler is made of, would eventually wear out (especially if You are levelling
Your building plate while it's hot) it would probably be wise to attach a more robust tip
to the ruler. Something with smooth edges like a steel ball, in order not to scratch Your
Capton surface ... I haven't had a good idea yet. Also, using a rubber band to keep the ruler under tension might be a good idea (the point is to have optimum contact between tip and surface for maximum precision). Well, this is work in project, okay? Now, for levelling all You have to do is move the tip of Your calibrator over each of the four
screws that level Your building plate. Turn the screws to have the exact same height in each of
the four positions and You're done.
You don't necessarily have to level Your plate at the exact height You're going to use later.
All You are doing here is to make sure You have the same height for all four points.

comments.text: I have to ask - if you're going to buy something to level your Replicator bed, why use Calipers instead of a Machinist's Dial Indicator? They designed for exactly this purpose - to measure distance from a tool to a surface extremely precisely, and have a "roller ball" tip so they move smoothly over the surface you're leveling. The analog ones are really cheap (e.g. $15 at http://www.harborfreight.com/1-inch-travel-machinists-dial-indicator-623.html)http://www.harborfreight.com/1..., and you can print a clip such as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43453http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... to hold it.

This holds the bottom of my shower curtain flush against the wall so water doesn't leak off the side of the tub!

The scad and stl are set up to fit a suction cup I had laying around, but you should be able to make it fit any suction cup with the following parameters:
CUP_STEM: the diameter of the neck of the suction cup stem
CUP_FLANGE: the diameter of the head/mushroom cap of the stem
FLATTENED_RAD: the radius of the suction cup when pressed down, mostly just draws the grey circle that makes it easier to fudge the other params :)

Also I added a place to mount the digital voltmeters. Left for the 12V motors, right for the 20V heated bed. It will slide over the top plate in a tilted angle. Beware: There are 3 versions.
V1 and V2 must be mounted right from the Z-stop. the V2 version is a bit lower, version 3 even lower and with smaller shaped legs.
V3 can be mounted left of the Z-stop screws with the left arm. If you want to add the voltmeters:

Thomas

Remember to deactivate the skirt in the expert settings in Cura! Otherwise it´s to big for the Printbot. ;)

author: boerzelmakes

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53940 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=53940

Using the following options: top_letter = None
left_side_letter = M
right_side_letter = M
typeface = blocks

Similar to a few other iPhone tripod mount options, my version features a hexagonal hole in the bottom, where an 11mm 20 TPI nut can be wedged/glued. The fit is pretty snug, so you may have to file it slightly to get the bolt to fit easily.
The mount also has a cutout on the bottom to use it as a viewing stand.
The design was primarily made with printability in mind, as I had some issues printing tripod mounts with a gorillapod-stye mount.
Sliced in Slic3r. 0.2 mm layer height, 15% infill, no support. Printed in PLA on Printrbot Simple Metal.

comments.text: Works great - the nut fit right in - using it with a gorilla mount. Just what I was looking for - nice work.
comments.author: ccrossaw

comments.text:
I just printed this and it came out beautifully. Buuuuut.... It doesn't fit an iPhone 5 at all. The slot is way to skinny. I can't find my calipers but the scale looks to be 6.6mm printed, the iphone 5 is 7.6mm deep.
Anyone know a good scaling to make it fit? Or and I getting out my dremel?
comments.author: Sandsman

comments.text: Sorry it didn't work out, what are you slicing with? Using slic3r, the dimensions should be 91.99 x 22 x 26. In the modeling software, the slot is 7.6 mm like you said. And I don't think it's an issue with the .STL, I printed the most recent version before I posted it. Maybe try scaling it to get those dimensions.
comments.author: Sandsman

comments.text:
Figured it out. I have been using RepG slicer but decided to jump to Slic3r. RepG had pretty accurate dimensional prints but Slic3r is printing about 93%-95% undersized (measured with 20mm calibration cube prints).
What setting do I need to tweak in Slic3r to fix this?
FYI printing to FlashForge with GPX converter
comments.author: JKoebele

comments.text: In Slic3r on the plater section, you'd just click on "scale" (top right), and try 105-107% scale since you said its printing 93-95% actual size. There may be a better way to fix the scaling correctly, but that's the only way I've done it.
